title: 112_hr6339
content: The Act is titled the "Electronic Communications Privacy Act Modernization Act of 2012" and requires a warrant for access to contents with notice rules. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Modernization Act of 2012 amends Section 2703(a) of title 18, United States Code, to require a warrant for disclosure of stored electronic communications by a service provider, with exceptions for warrants issued by a court or under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Modernization Act of 2012 amends Section 2703(a) of title 18, United States Code, requiring notification to subscribers within three days of receiving communication contents, and prohibits disclosure of customer communications by service providers to governmental entities. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Modernization Act of 2012 amends Section 2703(a) of title 18, United States Code, requiring notification to subscribers within three days of receiving communication contents and prohibits disclosure of customer communications by service providers to governmental entities. Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include delayed notice provisions. "Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code, includes delayed notice provisions." The government can request a delay in notifying individuals about a warrant under section 2703(a) for up to 90 days if there is a reason to believe that notification could have negative consequences. Adverse results include endangering individuals, flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or jeopardizing an investigation. Extensions can be granted upon application. Upon expiration of the delay period granted under section 2703(a), the government must provide the customer with a copy of the warrant and notify them of the nature of the law enforcement inquiry, information disclosure, delayed notification, and court determination. The government can delay notifying the customer under section 2703, and the method of providing required matter can be through various means specified by the court issuing the warrant. Additionally, a governmental entity can apply to a court to prevent a provider of electronic communications service from notifying any other person about the existence of the warrant. The court can order a delay in notifying others about the warrant for up to 90 days if it believes that notification will have adverse consequences. SEC. 3. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Chapter 121 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include reporting requirements for disclosures of wire or electronic communications. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts has the authority to make rules regarding the content and form of these reports. Judges must report to the Administrative Office within 30 days of issuing or denying an order for disclosure, including the type of order applied for. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts must report to Congress annually on the total number of orders for disclosure of wire or electronic communications, including details such as the type of order, modifications, denials, delayed notice, applying agency, and information sought. In January of each year, the Attorney General, the Secretary of Homeland Security, and prosecuting attorneys must report the number of accounts for voluntary disclosures under specific sections to the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts must report to Congress annually on voluntary disclosures made under specific sections, including a summary of the basis for disclosure and an analysis of the information reported. Provider reporting requirements mandate that each provider of electronic communication or remote computing services must report the number of legal demands received from Federal law enforcement agencies for records or contents of communications in the preceding calendar year to the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. The reporting requirements for providers of electronic communication or remote computing services include disclosing the number of legal demands from State and local law enforcement agencies for records or contents of communications in the previous year, as well as the number of accounts for which information was disclosed. The reporting requirements for providers of electronic communication or remote computing services include disclosing numbers of legal demands from law enforcement agencies and voluntary disclosures, with exceptions for providers receiving minimal requests or having a small customer base. Compensation may be provided by the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Court. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts may compensate providers for compiling required reports. Procedures are in place to protect the identity of service providers. An annual report to Congress includes the total legal demands and disclosures made in the previous year. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts may compensate providers for compiling required reports. An annual report to Congress includes the total legal demands and disclosures made in the previous year, along with a summary and analysis of the information without disclosing the identity of any service provider. SEC. 4. The Attorney General will conduct a study on mobile tracking devices under section 3117 within two years of enactment. SEC. 5. Reports on pen registers and trap and trace devices will be submitted to Congress. Section 3126 of title 18 is amended to require judges to report to the Administrative Office of the United States Courts within 30 days after the expiration of an order for a pen register or trap and trace device. The report must include details such as whether the order was granted, modified, or denied, the period of interceptions authorized, the offense specified, and the number and nature of facilities affected. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts must report to Congress annually on the number of applications for pen register orders and trap and trace devices, as well as provide a summary and analysis of the information required by the law. SEC. 6. Transition provision related to reporting requirements under amendments made by this act states that any reporting requirement to the Administrative Office of the United States Courts from this act will not take effect until a year after enactment. SEC. 7. Makes suppression remedies the same for intercepted wire, oral, and electronic communications. Section 2518 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include electronic communications, and paragraph (c) is removed. Section 2515 is also amended to include electronic communications.
